answers.answer: Hi!I can understand your worries. An increased T1 signal can indicate deposition of fat, proteins, melanin, contrast agent or gadolinium. It can also occur in case of hemorrhage or metabolic disorders like diabetes. Sometimes an increased T1 signal is an artifact or false result. A T2 hypointense lesion is usually cystic colloid lesions of unknown cause or MS lesion (less likely as they are usually multiple) or due to lacunar infarction, cystic neoplasms, and cystic periventricular leukomalacia. I know these names will not mean much to you, but your husband needs further tests to rule out these conditions one by one.Sometimes the lesion is of not much significance, especially if there are no symptoms. Please discuss in detail with your doctor or take a second opinion. Hope this helps. Take care!The medical advice given should not be considered a substitute for medical care provided by a doctor who can examine you.
